content.value: The socio-economic and geographical context of Latin America and the Caribbean

Latin America and the Caribbean (hereafter “LAC”) is composed of 48 separate administrative units including 33 countries and 15 dependent territories with a range of governance and political systems. It is a heterogenous region spanning approximately 20 million square kilometres (km
), about 15% of the global land area
. It covers two hemispheres, three oceans and a multitude of ecosystems.
With 660 million inhabitants of European, African, Asian and Indigenous descent (about 8.3% of the world’s population), the region boasts a diverse cultural and ethnic heritage
. Indigenous populations, while of great variety, contribute to the region’s shared understandings, especially with respect to nature and biodiversity.

Economic development and social wellbeing are closely linked to the natural environment and the quality of the ecosystem services it provides. Climate change presents multiple challenges. The region is very vulnerable to climate-related impacts on the lives and livelihoods of millions of people, and governments need to mitigate emissions while ensuring the climate transition takes into account the most vulnerable population groups and the protection and sustainable management of ecosystems.

In 2021, the economy of the LAC region represented 5% of global gross domestic product (GDP) (about 5 trillion USD). Average GDP per capita was USD 17 383 (at PPPs), less than half the OECD average of USD 43 115

. However, there are significant differences across countries (up to seven times), with Chile and Panama, and some Caribbean islands, having the highest income, and Nicaragua, Honduras and Haiti the lowest.

Although there are substantial social and economic differences across the region, most countries have been affected deeply by the COVID-19 pandemic and the global economic downturn. GDP plunged by 8.2% in 2020, compared to 4.2% in the OECD and 3.2% globally
Before the COVID-19 pandemic, GDP growth of the LAC region was already more modest (at an annual average of about +0.4% between 2010 and 2019) than in the OECD (about +2.0%) and globally (+3.4%).

Due to high energy prices and repercussions of economic slowdown in China, as well as number of structural issues affecting potential growth, the region is not expected to resume high levels of economic growth experienced in the 2000s. The socio‑economic consequences of COVID‑19 linger, with high levels of poverty and income inequality
The region has a diverse economy, but mainly based on activities that use and process natural resources. Agriculture and industry
Including mining, manufacturing, construction, electricity, water, and gas.

account for a larger share of value added than in OECD countries: in 2021, they contributed to 7% and 30% of value added respectively, compared to OECD averages of 1.8% and 24.4% respectively. Trade also plays an important role with exports accounting for 27% of GDP and imports 28%. Main exports include petroleum, ores, soya beans, passenger cars and trucks, that together account for more than a fourth of total exports. Intermediate goods account for 65% of LAC imports, reflecting the region’s strong industrial base although it is centred in only few large countries

Fertile soils and mild climates have made agriculture a major economic and social activity. The region’s cash crops include coffee and cacao, as well as industrial crops such as corn, soya and wheat. Grazing animals such a sheep, llamas, alpacas, and vicuñas are bred for their meat and their wool, which is used in high quality textiles exported worldwide. The Pampa’s vast pastures feed South America’s livestock. Due to the Humboldt current coming from Antarctica, fisheries are an important economic activity along LAC’s Pacific coast, but overfishing has led to the depletion of many fish populations. Forestry is a major economic activity in the Amazon River basin and the south of Chile which is an important exporter of wood chips, plywood and paper pulp.

Manufacturing industries accounted for 15% of the region’s GDP in 2021. Industries such as automotive and electronics (such as large-scale solar panels and televisions) play a key role in large countries such as Brazil and Mexico – the former having a significant maquila industry associated with the North American Free Trade Agreement and other trade arrangements across Central America.

Mining and energy are among LAC’s most important sectors, as the region is endowed in valuable minerals, including copper and lithium, and significant oil and natural gas deposits. Venezuela alone accounts for 24% of the world’s oil reserves
and around 4% of global natural gas reserves
. Hydropower is nevertheless the main source for electricity generation in the LAC region, generating 54% of electricity in 2020

. The region also has an important copper and lithium production, -more than a quarter of the world’s lithium production, with Chile accounting 26% of the total mine production in the world during 2020

Tourism plays a significant role, particularly in Central America and the Caribbean. In 2018, inbound tourism expenditure contributed to more than half of GDP in Caribbean islands such as Turks and Caicos (77%), Aruba (72%), Antigua and Barbuda (60%), Montserrat (55%) and Saint Lucia (51%). In Central America, under a quarter of GDP came from inbound tourism in 2018, with the highest being Belize (25%), followed by Panama (11%), Costa Rica (6%), El Salvador (5%) and Nicaragua (4%). South America derives less than 5% of its GDP from tourism, contributing to 4% of GDP in Uruguay in 2018, and 2% in Bolivia, Peru, Suriname, Ecuador and Colombia

Notwithstanding the considerable economic diversity across the region, most countries base their economic development on natural resources or ecosystem services. This suggests that climate change generates significant challenges for the region, either through the impacts associated with climate-related hazards that will affect activities such as agriculture, tourism, forestry, fisheries, and hydroelectricity, or the expected energy transition which will affect the viability of fossil fuel production and even the light manufacturing industry associated with the maquila industry.
Source: OECD, "Green growth indicators", OECD Environment Statistics (database),
The population of the LAC region is predominantly urban (81% in 2020), In South America 85% of the population lives in urban areas, followed by Central America (75%) and the Caribbean (67%)
. The Caribbean has the highest population density, with an average 300 inhabitants per km
in 2021, followed by Central America (106 inhabitants per km
) and South America (25 inhabitants per km

). The high level of urbanisation poses many challenges with respect to environmental issues, on the one hand air pollution is concentrated in urban centres and, on the other, island with high population density are more exposed to climate-related hazards.
The LAC region is historically characterised by high levels of income inequality and urban-rural disparities. Income inequality quantified by the Gini coefficient averaged 0.46 in 2021,
compared to an OECD average of 0.34
. Differences across countries are considerable; the Gini coefficient ranges from 0.40 in the Dominican Republic and Uruguay to 0.54 in Brazil
Poverty is a major concern, particularly in urban areas where about 32% of the inhabitants lived in extreme poverty in 2021, compared to 13% in rural areas
. While this gap has narrowed since the beginning of the millennium, progress has stagnated in the past decade and the economic crisis following the pandemic has aggravated the situation.

During the COVID-19 pandemic, the region experienced one of the highest mortality rates in the world due to the high population concentration in urban areas and unequal access to health services. Brazil, Peru and Ecuador were especially affected with economic and social impacts. Latin America and the Caribbean lost 2.9 years of life expectancy at birth between 2019 and 2021
. Such vulnerability in health systems  as well as high public debt across the region – on average 65% of GDP in 2020 and over a 100% in some countries

– limits the capacity to deal effectively with the impacts of climate change. Given the close relationship between economic subsistence and environmental conditions, large groups of the population are likely to be very vulnerable to changes in the global and local environment.
Source: OECD, "Green growth indicators", OECD Environment Statistics (database),

Due to differences in elevation across the region – from lowlands in Mexico and Brazil, to Andean peaks just under 7 000 metres – and the impact of warm currents from the Atlantic Ocean and cold currents from the Pacific Ocean, LAC has a wide variety of climatic conditions, ranging from tropical, to temperate, to arid. This varied climate and physical geography facilitates a range of biomes and ecosystems, including close to 4 million hectares of permanent snow and glaciers, over 4 million hectares of mangroves, and over 70 million hectares of Ramsar-designated wetlands
making the region the home of about 50% of the world’s biodiversity and one-third of global fresh water sources

. According to the UN Environment’s World Conservation Monitoring Centre six Latin American countries are a considered to be mega-diverse (17 in the world), namely Brazil, Colombia, Ecuador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.

LAC is home to 23% of the world’s forests, including the Amazon, the world’s largest rain forest which is shared by eight countries. South America has the largest forest cover, averaging 48% of total land area in 2020

. This is driven by countries such as Suriname, Guyana, Brazil, Peru, Colombia, Venezuela and Ecuador, where forests cover more than half of the land area. In Central America forests represent 36% of the land area and in the Caribbean 35% (

). Many high-value tree species, such as mahogany and rosewood, are native to the rainforest. However, forests are under threat, between 1990 and 2020, the proportion of regional forest cover decreased from 53% to 46% of total territory
. With the exception of Chile and Costa Rica, all LAC countries have suffered a significant net loss in forested areas.

The region contains around 650 million hectares of agricultural area, including meadows and pastures, arable land and permanent crops, of which Brazil counts with the largest area in absolute terms (over 236 million hectares). The area of arable and cropland varies across sub regions. It covers 30% of the land in the Caribbean, 12% in Central America and 8% in South America. Countries that show the highest share of agricultural area include Uruguay, Haiti, Cuba, El Salvador, the Dominican Republic and Mexico (

). Countries with high proportions of agricultural area under organic farming in the region include Uruguay (19% in 2020), French Guiana (11%), Dominican Republic (5%) and Argentina (4%). Land use policies will need to take into account the central role agricultural systems play in LAC economies and societies, representing an important source of income, employment and food for the region and the world
Source: OECD, “Land resources: Land use”, OECD Environment Statistics (database),

Due to its reliance on natural resources, high inequalities and levels of poverty, LAC is one of the most vulnerable regions in the world to climate change. The region’s economy and the population’s well-being is highly affected either directly, through the exposure to changing climate and climate-related hazards, or indirectly, through the impacts on economic activities associated with the energy transition.

Climate change impacts are already challenging the fiscal sustainability of the region when natural disasters strike, and key economic sectors will be increasingly affected by longer term changes. Rising temperatures, fluctuating rainfall patterns, melting glaciers, and the increased occurrence of extreme weather events pose risks to the Latin American hydroelectric power system. Increasing temperatures and drought conditions are putting pressure on the agricultural sector and forestry activities, also increasing the risk of wildfires. Expected domestic and international policies to ensure climate mitigation (e.g. reduction of fossil fuel consumption) may reduce the region’s financial resources. Many tourist areas will be affected by increasing sea levels and climate-related hazards.

However, climate change and the transition to less carbon intensive economies also creates opportunities, generating new economic activities. Growing demands for renewable energy sources, lithium and copper and other key minerals, as well as the potential to implement nature-based solutions suggests that structural changes could help the region move towards a more sustainable, resilient and inclusive development model. This model should help close the existing social, economic, institutional and environmental development gaps and avoid generating new ones.
Before the COVID-19 pandemic, GDP growth of the LAC region was already more modest (at an annual average of about +0.4% between 2010 and 2019) than in the OECD (about +2.0%) and globally (+3.4%).
